questions.question: A 55-year-old female fell on her left shoulder while walking and now presents with severe pain, swelling, and bruising. Based on the X-ray shown below, what is the most common mechanism of injury and the likely affected structure?

options.B: Fall on an outstretched hand, Radial nerve
options.D: Fall on an outstretched hand, Axillary nerve

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Fall on an outstretched hand, Axillary nerve Explanation: The provided X-ray indicates a left proximal humerus fracture , typically caused by a fall on an outstretched hand, commonly affecting the axillary nerve. Proximal Humerus Fracture Shaft of Humerus Fracture Mechanism of injury Fall on an outstretched hand (Option D) Direct trauma (Option C) Structures affected Axillary artery Axillary nerve (Option D) Brachial artery Radial nerve (Option C) Complications Joint stiffness (most common) Avascular necrosis (AVN) Nerve injury: Axillary nerve (most common) Suprascapular nerve injury Non-union Shoulder dislocation Myositis Malunion Early: Nerve injury: Radial nerve (wrist drop) Late: Delayed and non-union Joint stiffness Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Pg no, 766-769.

questions.question: A 34-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe pain and swelling in her right forearm after a biking accident. She has difficulty flexing her ring and pinky fingers. Examination reveals swelling, limited flexion of the fourth and fifth fingers, pallor, diminished pulse, and paresthesia in the affected fingers. What is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Turn Buckle’s Splint Explanation: The scenario describes Tsuge’s type I Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture (VIC) involving only the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) . The appropriate management in this case would be the use of a Turn Buckle splint. Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture (VIC) Management Type Management Mild (Tsuge's Type-I) Turn Buckle's splint (Volkmann's splinting) (Option A) Physiotherapy Total excision (single muscle involved) Moderate (Tsuge's Type-II) Max page's operation (Soft tissue sliding operation) (Option B) Excision of cicatrix Neurolysis (freeing the peripheral nerves from the surrounding fibrous tissue) Severe (Tsuge's Type-III) Seddon's carpectomy: (Option C) Excision of the scar Arthrodesis of the wrist Amputation (cases with gangrene) (Option D)

questions.question: A 28-year-old female with a history of a left lateral condylar fracture presents with left elbow pain, especially during lifting or reaching overhead. She notices her left arm appears straighter than her right. Examination shows lateral deviation of the forearm when her arms are extended. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Cubitus valgus Explanation: The scenario described, including the reported symptoms and the lateral deviation of the forearm when the arm is extended, points to a diagnosis of Cubitus Valgus . Description An acquired deformity due to reduced growth on the lateral side of the distal humeral epiphysis. Cause Non-union of lateral condylar fracture Clinical feature A carrying angle of the elbow greater than 15 degrees Asymmetry between the two side Lateral deviation of the forearm during arm extension Management Usually, no treatment is required Supracondylar osteotomy (in severe cases) Complication Tardy ulnar nerve palsy: Managed by anterior transposition of the ulnar nerve. Gunstock deformity (Option A) is also known as cubitus varus. It is caused by malunion of a supracondylar fracture in childhood. Dinner fork deformity (Option C) occurs due to a Colles' fracture. In this condition, the radial styloid process is positioned at or slightly above the level of the ulnar styloid process, creating the characteristic appearance of a dinner fork. Coxa vara (Option D) is a hip deformity characterised by a reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur. This condition can be congenital or acquired (Inter-trochanteric fracture).

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling from a tree. X-rays reveal a displaced supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The child is experiencing severe pain, and upon examination, the forearm appears swollen and tense. Which of the following is the first sign of impending compartment syndrome??

options.A: Absence of the radial pulse on examination
options.B: Pain that intensifies with passive finger extension
options.C: Immediate improvement in pain with elevation of the arm

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pain that intensifies with passive finger extension Explanation: The first sign of impending compartment syndrome is typically pain that worsens with passive stretching of the muscles in the affected compartment. (Stretch Test) Compartment Syndrome: It occurs when increased pressure within a limb's muscle compartments compromises blood flow to the muscles and nerves, potentially leading to severe complications. Causes: Common in children : Most frequently caused by supracondylar fractures. Adults : Often due to crush injuries; other causes include: Fractures of both bones of the forearm and elbow dislocations Vascular injuries and Subfascial hematomas. The flexor muscles, particularly the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus , are most commonly affected. Volkmann's ischemic contracture (VIC) may develop due to arterial spasm, leading to muscle ischemia and eventual fibrosis. The 6 Ps of Impending Volkmann’s Ischemia: Pain Pallor Paresthesia Paralysis Pulselessness Positive passive stretch test Diagnosis: Severe, poorly localised pain disproportionate to injury. Swelling, redness, warmth, tenderness, and tension in the forearm Stretch test : Pain occurs when ischemic muscles are stretched - the first sign of impending compartment syndrome . Other signs: Initially, palpable peripheral pulses may later become absent. Nerve involvement (Median nerve > Ulnar nerve) Treatment: Preventive measures, such as limb elevation and active finger movements, can help mitigate risks. Acute stage (Surgical Emergency): Removing any tight bandages & monitor intracompartmental pressure: Pressure > 30 mm Hg - Emergency fasciotomy Pressure < 30 mm Hg - Continuous monitoring Absence of the radial pulse on examination (Option A) indicates severe ischemia, which occurs when blood flow is critically compromised due to elevated compartment pressure & is not an early sign. Immediate improvement in pain with elevation of the arm (Option C) is not typical of compartment syndrome. Pain is not alleviated unless pressure is reduced in the compartment. Numbness in the forearm (Option D) can occur as a result of nerve compression due to increased compartment pressure, but it is a later sign.

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a fall while playing rugby. He has severe pain and swelling in his elbow, and the physician suspects injury to the terrible triad. Which of the following is NOT a component of the terrible triad of the elbow?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Fracture of the medial epicondyle Explanation: A fracture of the medial epicondyle is not included in the terrible triad of the elbow. Terrible Triad of the Elbow: It refers to a specific injury pattern involving three components, commonly seen in elbow dislocations, particularly after trauma: Posterior elbow dislocation (Option A) Fracture of the radial head (Option B) Fracture of the coronoid process (Option C) Mechanism of Injury: Typically results from a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow slightly flexed. A valgus twist can lead to a posterolateral dislocation. Treatment: The standard treatment involves reduction under anaesthesia, followed by immobilisation in an above-elbow cast.

questions.question: A 7-year-old child presents to the emergency department after falling on an outstretched hand. The examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the lateral aspect of the elbow. X-rays show the findings as shown in the image. What classification system is used to categorize this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Milch Classification Explanation: The clinical scenario and the distinct line observed in the lateral condyle on the X-ray indicate a lateral condylar fracture . The Milch classification is specifically used for lateral condylar fractures. Lateral Condylar Fracture: Mechanism of Injury: Typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow extended and forced into varus, leading to a shearing or avulsion fracture of the lateral condyle. Clinical Features: Swelling and deformity of the elbow. Tenderness over

questions.question: A 10-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after falling onto an outstretched hand. X-rays reveal a finding, as shown in the image. Traction is applied as part of the management, as depicted in the accompanying image. What is the name of the traction being used?
A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department after falling onto an outstretched hand. X-ray shows the following findings. What is the most appropriate management?

options.A: Long arm cast immobilization for 3 weeks

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Closed reduction and percutaneous pinning Explanation: The scenario of a fall on an outstretched hand, with an X-ray showing a supracondylar fracture of the humerus and completely displaced fractures, indicates a Type III Gartland fracture. Management involves closed reduction followed by percutaneous pinning for stabilization Gartland Classification of Supracondylar Fractures Type I Nondisplaced fractures. Long arm cast immobilisation (Option A) for 3 weeks, followed by a period of protected activity Type II Fracture with an intact posterior hinge. Type IIA Stable fractures with no significant translation or rotation Closed reduction &

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy fell on his outstretched hand and was presented with pain, swelling and restricted movement of the elbow, along with an S-shaped deformity. An X-ray was performed; What is the most common type of below fracture diagnosed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Extension type, Posteromedial Explanation: The clinical presentation and radiograph suggests an extension type of supracondylar fracture, where posteromedial displacement is the most common. Supracondylar fractures are classified into two types: extension and flexion. Aspects Extension type Flexion Type Frequency More common Rare (Option A and C) Location The distal part of the humerus is extended. The distal part of the humerus is flexed Subtypes Posteromedial (more common) Posterolateral (Option B) Anteromedial Anterolateral Complications Radial nerve injury (Posteromedial) Median nerve injury

questions.question: An 18-year-old male presents with difficulty flexing the distal phalanx of her index and middle fingers, along with weakness in thumb opposition and forearm pronation. He also reports pain, swelling, and limited movement in his elbow following a fall on his left hand. An X-ray was taken. Which of the following nerves is commonly affected in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Anterior interosseous nerve Explanation: The clinical presentation and X-ray suggest a supracondylar humerus fracture, which commonly affects the anterior interosseous nerve , a branch of the median nerve. This nerve innervates the flexor pollicis longus and the lateral half of the flexor digitorum profundus , which is responsible for flexing the distal phalanx of the index and middle fingers. Weakness in thumb

questions.question: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the clinic after falling on her outstretched hand, resulting in severe pain in her left elbow. The examination shows swelling and tenderness in the elbow, and she is reluctant to move her arm. An x-ray has been taken. Which of the following is false regarding the 3 bony point relationship in this fracture?

options.A: Three points form a nearly isosceles triangle when the elbow is flexed at 90°.
options.B: Medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, and tip of the olecranon are the three bony points.
options.C: Bony relationship is unaffected by elbow fractures.
options.D: Bony point relationship are unaffected in Supracondylar fractures

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Bony relationship is unaffected by elbow fractures. Explanation: The X-ray shows a supracondylar fracture of the humerus , where the three-point bony relationship is usually normal (Option D) due to the fracture's location above the elbow joint or minimal displacement. In a normally flexed elbow at 90°, these three bony points form a nearly isosceles triangle (Option A) . The three-point bony relationship consists of

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his left upper arm and wrist drop after a fall while playing football. Examination reveals weakness in wrist extension and numbness over the dorsum of his hand. Radiographs show a humeral fracture. Which part of the humerus is most likely involved in this fracture?

options.B: Junction of the middle and distal third
options.C: Junction of the proximal and middle third

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Junction of the middle and distal third Explanation: This fracture, known as a Holstein-Lewis fracture, typically occurs at the junction of the middle and distal third of the humeral shaft and is associated with radial nerve injury , leading to wrist drop and sensory loss over the dorsum of the hand. Mechanism of injury: Fall on outstretched hand or direct trauma to the arm. Management: Conservative: There is no role for conservative management in Holstein-lewis fracture The treatment of choice is emergency decompression For stable fractures, the initial management may include: U-slab or Hanging cast Chest arm bandage to immobilise the arm Surgical Intervention: In cases of displaced fractures or complicated cases: Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF) Intramedullary nailing Compression plating and screws External fixation Dynamic cock-up splint is used primarily to support the wrist and hand while allowing for some movement. It is designed to maintain the wrist in a neutral position (slightly extended) while permitting the fingers to flex and extend. Nerve damage is usually temporary, but in case of open fractures exploration might be needed. Supracondylar region (Option A): Fractures in the supracondylar region typically affect the median nerve , leading to symptoms such as weakness in wrist flexion and the " hand of benediction" sign. These fractures are more common in children and are less likely to cause wrist drop. Junction of the proximal and middle third (Option C) & Surgical neck of the humerus (Option D): Fractures at these locations primarily affect the axillary nerve. This results in weakness of the deltoid muscle , causing difficulty in arm abduction and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder.

questions.question: A 48-year-old female fell on her outstretched right hand and reported shoulder pain. A bruise was noted during the examination, and an X-ray was performed. How would you classify this fracture according to Neer's classification based on the X-ray findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Two-part fracture Explanation: The given X-ray image depicts 2 part fracture of Neer’s classification which says 1 displaced part with fracture line involving 2 or 3 parts. Neer’s classification of Proximal humerus fractures is based on the number of displaced fragments, where displacement is angulation > 45° or a separation > 1 cm and is helpful in guiding the treatment decisions. The four parts of the proximal humerus are Greater tuberosity Lesser tuberosity Head of the humerus Shaft of the humerus Neer’s Classification Management 1 Part Fracture The fracture line involves 1 part and no displacement. Conservative with an arm sling for 6 weeks, followed by exercises. Triangular arm sling Velpeau bandage 2 Part Fracture The fracture line involves two parts and displacement of 1 part. Surgical neck displacement: Closed reduction and immobilization with arm-sling or k-wire . Greater tuberosity displaced (mostly associated with shoulder dislocation): Open

questions.question: A 29-year-old boxer received a blow to his arm and presented to the emergency department with severe pain, swelling, and deformity in his left upper arm. He reports difficulty moving his elbow and hand and weakness in his wrist. An X-ray was taken. All the following are management options for this condition except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Velpeau bandage Explanation: The scenario describes a humeral shaft fracture, with management options including a U-slab, hanging cast, and plate osteosynthesis. However, a Velpeau bandage is used for proximal humerus fractures, not shaft fractures. Management of fracture of shaft of the humerus: a) Conservative management Type Description Image U-slab (Option A) Supported with a triangular sling Moulded on the lateral side of the arm (prevent lateral angulation) Hanging arm cast (Option B) Used in lower 1/3rd

questions.question: A 26-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain and tenderness after sustaining an injury from a fall. An X-ray of the region is provided below. Considering the mechanisms of injury, what is the most common cause associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Fall on the shoulder Explanation: The scenario with X-ray findings points towards a right Clavicular fracture, most commonly caused by a fall directly onto the shoulder . Clavicle or Collarbone : It is a long, slightly S-shaped bone located horizontally at the junction of the neck and trunk. It articulates medially with the sternum and the cartilage of the first rib and laterally with the acromion process of the scapula. Structural features: It is the only long bone that lies horizontally , does not contain a medullary cavity ,

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents with recurrent shoulder dislocations after playing basketball & shows the attitude as shown in the image. Which of the following tests is specifically used to assess this shoulder instability?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sulcus test Explanation: The scenario along with the attitude showing abducted arm above the head with external rotation suggests Inferior shoulder dislocation . The Sulcus sign is specifically designed to assess inferior shoulder instability by evaluating the presence of a gap between the humeral head and the acromion. A positive sulcus sign indicates inferior instability or laxity in the shoulder joint. Tests for shoulder instability: a) Anterior instability Test Description Image Apprehension test (Option D) With the patient seated or supine, the examiner abducts the arm and externally rotates it. The patient may feel the humeral head about to slip anteriorly, leading to tension and apprehension. Fulcrum test (Option A) With the patient lying supine and the arm abducted to 90°, the examiner uses one hand behind the shoulder as a fulcrum to lever the humeral head forward by extending and laterally rotating the arm, leading to immediate apprehension. Crank test With the arm flexed at 90°, the examiner applies an axial load to the humerus and rotates it while elevating the shoulder. A positive test

questions.question: A 32-year-old male arrives at the emergency department with severe right shoulder pain after a fall during a workout. His shoulder appears deformed, with swelling and bruising. An orthopaedic manoeuvre is performed, as shown in the image. What is the name of this technique?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Stimson technique Explanation: In this scenario, the patient's shoulder deformity, severe pain, and fall history suggest a Right anterior shoulder dislocation. The manoeuvre in the image is the Stimson technique , which reduces the dislocation by using a weight for traction and the body providing counter traction. Hippocrates technique (Option A) is an outdated method for shoulder dislocation reduction. The surgeon pulls firmly on the semi-abducted arm while placing a foot in the axilla, using it as a fulcrum to guide the humeral head back into place. Milch technique (Option C) involves manipulating the humeral head by applying traction to the arm, combined with external rotation and abduction, facilitating the repositioning of the humeral head into the glenoid cavity. Gallows traction (Option D) is a type of continuous traction used to reduce femur shaft fractures in children. It involves suspending the child's body from a frame, allowing the affected limb to hang freely. This

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency after a soccer match with severe right shoulder pain following a fall. He reports a "pop" in his shoulder and is unable to lift his arm or touch the opposite shoulder. An X-ray has been taken. What is the appropriate management for this condition? → Adduction → Traction → Medial rotation → Medial rotation → Adduction → External rotation → External rotation → Adduction → Medial rotation → Traction → External rotation → Adduction
questions.explanation: → External rotation → Adduction → Medial rotation Correct Answer: C) Traction → External rotation → Adduction → Medial rotation Explanation: The clinical presentation and X-ray suggest the diagnosis of Right Anterior shoulder dislocation , typically managed using the Kocher technique .

questions.question: An 18-year-old male presents with severe pain in his right shoulder following a tackle during a rugby match. Upon examination, a loss of normal shoulder contour is noted. Diagnosis of anterior shoulder dislocation was made. What is the most common complication associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Recurrence Explanation: Recurrent shoulder dislocation is the most common complication following an initial dislocation. It occurs due to repeated trauma, capsular laxity, bone changes, muscle weakness, inadequate rehabilitation, or high-risk activities. Hill-Sachs and Bankart lesions , associated with shoulder dislocations, contribute to joint instability and increase the risk of recurrence. Complications of Shoulder Dislocation: Early Complications Delayed Complications Rotator cuff tear - Common in the elderly due to degenerative changes in the tendons and less common in younger patients. (Option B) Axillary artery injury - Rare; Occurs with severe trauma (Option B) Nerve injury - The axillary nerve is most commonly affected; other nerve injuries and complete brachial plexus palsy are rare. (Option A) Recurrence - Most common, due to instability. Joint stiffness - Results from prolonged immobility. Unreduced dislocation - Due to missed or undiagnosed dislocation. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page 763, 764, 386.

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident with severe pain and immobility in his right shoulder. Examination reveals a flattened shoulder, and he is unable to abduct or externally rotate the arm. An X-ray was taken. What type of dislocation is suspected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Subcoracoid Explanation: Based on the clinical presentation and mechanism of injury, a subcoracoid dislocation is suspected. This is the most common type of anterior shoulder dislocation , where the humeral head typically displaces forward and downward toward the coracoid process. Anterior Shoulder dislocation Subtypes Subglenoid (Option C) : The humeral head lies below the glenoid fossa. Subclavicular (Option B) : The humeral head is displaced beneath the clavicle. Intrathoracic (Option A) : The humeral head

questions.question: A 36-year-old male with shoulder pain and recurrent anterior dislocations reports instability and weakness during overhead activities. An X-ray is advised. What lesion was observed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hill-Sachs lesion Explanation: The X-ray reveals a posterolateral defect in the left humeral head, known as a Hill-Sachs lesion, typically resulting from impingement by the anterior edge of the glenoid during dislocation (often referred to as hatchet deformity ) . Aspects Hill-Sachs lesion (Option D) Bankart lesion (Option C) Reverse Bankart lesion (Posterior Bankart) (Option A) Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion (Option B) Location Humeral head Anterior glenoid Posterior glenoid Humeral head Definition Compression fracture on the posterolateral humeral head Defect in the anterior labrum and the anterior capsule. Tear of the posterior labrum and the associated capsule. Compression fracture on the anteromedial humeral head. Symptoms Instability and pain during shoulder movements Associated Shoulder dislocation type Anterior Anterior Posterior Posterior (Surgical correction of this lesion is necessary to prevent osteonecrosis) Reverse Hill Sachs Lesion Bankart’s

questions.question: Match the following images with appropriate tests. 1. a) Dugas test 2. b) Callaway test 3. c) Hamilton ruler test 4. d) Regimen batch sign

A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a seizure. He has severe pain and immobility in his right shoulder, which appears flattened and is held in an adducted and internally rotated position. An X-ray is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Posterior shoulder dislocation Explanation: The X-ray shows an abnormally shaped humeral head resembling an electric light bulb (due to internal rotation of the greater tubercle) , with slight displacement away from the glenoid fossa, indicating the "empty glenoid" sign. These findings, along with the history of seizures resulting in trauma, strongly suggest a diagnosis of posterior shoulder dislocation. Clinically, the patient presents with severe pain and immobility in the right shoulder, which appears flattened and is held in adduction and internal rotation as the humeral head shifts behind the glenoid cavity, causing the arm to be drawn close to the body. Types of Shoulder dislocations: Aspects Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation Inferior dislocation Frequency Most common Not very common Rare Mechanism of Injury Fall on an outstretched hand with an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. Occurs during seizures or convulsions . A fall onto a flexed, adducted arm . A direct impact to the anterior aspect of the shoulder . A fall onto an outstretched hand . Also called luxatio erecta. Result from a severe hyper-abduction force. Clinical presentation Pain, swelling and movement

questions.question: A 30-year-old male athlete presents with shoulder pain and instability after a football injury. Examination reveals anterior dislocation of the humeral head. Which of the following provides static stability to the shoulder joint?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) c Explanation: Among the given options, the Capsule (marked as c) serves as a static stabilizer of the shoulder joint, while the Supraspinatus(a), the long head of the biceps(d), and Teres minor(b) act as dynamic stabilizers. Shoulder Joint: (Glenohumeral joint) It is formed by the articulation of the head of the humerus with the glenoid cavity of the scapula. While it is the most mobile joint in the body, its wide range of motion contributes to its instability, resulting in a high risk of dislocations. Static Stabilizers Dynamic Stabilizers Glenoid labrum : Enhances stability by deepening the glenoid cavity. Glenohumeral ligaments (Superior, Middle, and Inferior Ligaments) form the glenohumeral joint capsule (c) , connecting the glenoid fossa to the humerus. Coracoclavicular ligament Coracohumeral ligament Long Head of the Biceps Tendon (d) : Provides stability and support. Rotator Cuff Muscles: Supraspinatus (a) : Assists in the abduction and stabilises the head of the humerus. Infraspinatus : External rotation and stabilisation. Teres Minor (b) : External rotation and

questions.question: A one-year-old child is brought to the emergency department after a fall, and the caregiver reports mild pain over the right shoulder while the child remains active. An X-ray is provided. What is the most appropriate treatment option for managing this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cuff and Collar Sling Explanation: The X-ray shows a right clavicular fracture in a one-year-old child with minimal displacement. In this case, symptomatic treatment with a cuff and collar sling is the most suitable option, providing adequate support and comfort during healing. Management of Clavicular Fracture: Clavicle fractures typically heal well; fragment reduction is not necessary, even if displaced. For minimal displacement, a triangular sling is adequate. Active shoulder exercises should begin once severe pain diminishes, usually around 10-14 days post-injury. Figure-of-‘8’ bandage (Option A) : This provides immobilisation and pain relief for young adults with displaced fractures and is not preferred for age <2 years. Conservative Methods: Cuff and Collar Sling : For undisplaced fractures to support the arm and shoulder. Strapping : After reducing the fracture, the arm is elevated, and the shoulder is braced upward and backward, yielding positive outcomes for both

questions.question: A 23-year-old male presents after a fall onto his shoulder. He complains of pain and difficulty moving the affected arm. Based on the clinical presentation and x-ray findings shown in the image, which of the following statements is true regarding the condition and its complications? Injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus is more common than medial cord Malunion is the most common complication Subclavian vessels are at more risk of injury Shoulder stiffness occurs as a late complication
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Statements 2,3 and 4 are true Explanation: The X-ray shows a left clavicular fracture , and Injury to the medial cord of the brachial plexus is more commonly associated with it. Complications of Clavicle Fracture: Early Complications: Neurovascular Injury : This can occur immediately from trauma or later due to callus formation. Commonly affected structures include: Subclavian vessels (Statement 3) Medial cord of the brachial plexus (ulnar nerve) (Statement 1) These injuries are most associated with fractures of the middle third, the most common site of clavicle fractures. Late Complications: Malunion (Most Common) (Statement 2) results from difficulty maintaining alignment, typically causing cosmetic deformity but rarely impairing function, so treatment is often unnecessary. Shoulder Stiffness (Statement 4) : Common, especially in older patients and early mobilization can help prevent this. Non-Union : This occurs in 1–15% of cases, and risk factors include age and displacement. Symptomatic cases may require plate fixation and bone grafting.

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient arrives at the emergency department after falling onto the shoulder & reports severe pain and tenderness in the shoulder, with noticeable swelling. X-ray findings are given in the image below. What is the most common site associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Medial 2/3rd & lateral 1/3rd junction Explanation: The given clinical scenario of a fall onto the shoulder with tenderness and swelling, as well as the X-ray findings, points towards a left clavicle fracture. Clavicular fracture most commonly occurs at the junction of the middle two-third and outer (lateral) thirds of the clavicle. This area is most vulnerable to injury due to the natural curvature of the bone and the forces exerted during trauma. It is the most common bone to be fractured in children. Displacement: The outer fragment tends to displace medially and downward due to gravity and the pull of the pectoralis major muscle. The inner fragment displaces upward because of the sternocleidomastoid muscle's pull. Allman’s Classification of Clavicular Fracture: Group I : Fractures involving the middle third of the shaft. Group II : Fractures involving the lateral third, distal to the coracoclavicular ligament, further subdivided into: (Proposed by Neer) Type A : Coracoclavicular ligament intact. Type B : Coracoclavicular ligament ruptured. Type C : Intra-articular extension into the acromioclavicular joint Group III : Fractures of the medial third. Radiographs: The following views are recommended for evaluating clavicle fractures: Routine Anteroposterior (AP) View of the clavicle. IIIIII Lordotic View if the fracture is uncertain. Special Radiographic Techniques like CT Scans are required for assessing the distal clavicle. Findings: Fracture Line : A clear line usually located in the middle third of the
